DUMMIES.details: Allows the creation of dummy entity behavior/resource files, as well as placing them in the world.

AUTOINIT.details: Runs the initialization file automatically in new worlds, and every time a new build is compiled. Requires a check-function to be run every tick.

EXPLODE.details: Allows the creation of exploder entity behavior/resource files. Allows the use of the explode command by generating presets for the entity.

UNINSTALL.details: Creates a function that will 'uninstall' the addon from the world; removes tags, scoreboard objectives, dummy entities, etc.

categories.preprocessor: Commands that allow the user to do things at compile time. Preprocessor commands generally start with a `$` and are highlighted differently than regular commands.
categories.text: Commands which display text to players through format-strings, or manipulate text otherwise.
categories.entities: Commands which manipulate, spawn, and transform entities in various ways.
categories.blocks: Commands which interact with the Minecraft world's blocks.
categories.items: Commands relating to entity/player items and inventories.
categories.cosmetic: Commands that add visual and auditory appeal to the user's code.
categories.values: Commands tied directly to values. Values can be used in if-statements, format-strings, and many other places.
categories.logic: Commands which handle logic and code flow. The butter for all the bread (code).
categories.debug: Commands related to testing, debugging and all-around solidifying code.
categories.features: Commands related to the optionally enable-able features in the language.
categories.other: The other commands that don't have a good designation.

$var.details: Sets a preprocessor variable to the value(s) provided.

$inc.details: Increments the given preprocessor variable by one. If multiple values are held, they are all incremented.

$dec.details: Decrements the given preprocessor variable by one. If multiple values are held, they are all decremented.

$add.details: Adds two preprocessor variables/values together, changing only the first one. A += B

$sub.details: Subtracts two preprocessor variables/values from each other, changing only the first one. A -= B

$mul.details: Multiplies two preprocessor variables/values together, changing only the first one. A *= B

$div.details: Divides two preprocessor variables/values from each other, changing only the first one. A /= B

$mod.details: Divides two preprocessor variables/values from each other, setting only the first one to the remainder of the operation. A %= B

$pow.details: Exponentiates two preprocessor variables/values with each other, changing only the first one. A = A^B

$swap.details: Swaps the values of two preprocessor variables

$append.details: Adds the given item(s) to the end of the given preprocessor variable, or contents of another preprocessor variable if specified.

$prepend.details: Adds the given item(s) to the start of the given preprocessor variable.

$if.details: Compares a preprocessor variable and another value/variable. If the source variable contains multiple values, they all must match the condition.

$else.details: Directly inverts the result of the last $if call at this level in scope.

$assert.details: Asserts that the input comparison is true, and throws a compiler error if not.

$repeat.details: Repeats the following statement/code-block a number of times. If a variable identifier is given, that variable will be set to the index of the current iteration. 0, 1, 2, etc.

$log.details: Sends a message to stdout with a line terminator at the end.

$macro.details: If a code-block follows this call, it is treated as a definition. Arguments are passed in as preprocessor variables. If no code-block follows this call, it will attempt to run the macro with any inputs parameters copied to their respective preprocessor variables.

$include.details: Places the contents of the given file in replacement for this statement. Not intended for production use yet.

$strfriendly.details: Convert the given preprocessor variable value(s) to a string in 'Title Case'.

$strupper.details: Convert the given preprocessor variable value(s) to a string in 'UPPERCASE'.

$strlower.details: Convert the given preprocessor variable value(s) to a string in 'lowercase'.

$sum.details: Adds all values in the given preprocessor variable together into one value and stores it in a result variable.

$median.details: Gets the middle value/average of the two middle values and stores it in a result variable.

$mean.details: Averages all values in the given preprocessor variable together into one value and stores it in a result variable.

$sort.details: Sorts the order of the values in the given preprocessor variable either 'ascending' or 'descending'. Values must be comparable.

$reverse.details: Reverses the order of the values in the given preprocessor variable.

$unique.details: Flattens the given preprocessor array to only unique values.

$iterate.details: Runs the following statement/code-block once for each value in the given preprocessor variable. The current iteration is held in the preprocessor variable given. If the target is a JSON array, the elements will be iterated upon.

$len.details: If a preprocessor variable identifier or JSON array is specified, the number of elements it holds is gotten. If a string is given, its length is gotten.

$json.details: Load a JSON file (if not previously loaded) and retrieve a value from it, storing said value in a preprocessor variable.

$call.details: Calls a function by name and passes in the given parameters. Because this is a preprocessor operation, it has the same error handling as a normal function call.

mc.details: Places a plain command in the output file, used for when the language lacks a certain feature.

globalprint.details: Prints a chat message to all players in the game. Supports format-strings.

print.details: Prints a chat message to the executing player, or to the given one if specified. Supports format-strings.

lang.details: Sets the active lang file (examples: en_US, pt_BR). Once set, all text will automatically be localized into that lang file; including format-strings.

define.details: Defines a variable with a name and type, defaulting to int if unspecified. Can be assigned a value directly after defining.

init.details: Ensures this variable has a value, defaulting to 0 if not. This ensures the executing entity(s) function as intended all the time. Use clarifiers to pick who the variable is initialized for: e.g., `variableName[@a]`

if.details: Allows comparison of variables, along with a huge collection of other criteria. Can be chained together by the keyword 'and' and inverted by the keyword 'not'. Only runs the proceeding statement/code-block for entities where the condition returns true.

else.details: Inverts the comparison given by the previous if-statement at this scope level.

assert.details: Asserts that the given condition evaluates to true, at runtime. If the condition evaluates to false, the code is halted and info is displayed to the executing player(s).

throw.details: Throws an error, displaying it to the executing player(s). The code is halted immediately, so handle cleanup before calling throw. Supports format-strings.

give.details: Gives item(s) to the given entity. Runs either a 'give' or 'structure load' depending on requirements. Utilizes builder fields.

tp.details: Teleports the executing/given entities to a specific position, selector, "name:type" of entity, or name of another managed entity (e.g., dummy entities).

move.details: Moves the specified entity in a direction (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN, FORWARD, BACKWARD) for a certain amount. Simpler alternative for teleporting using caret offsets.

face.details: Faces the given entities towards a specific position, selector, "name:type" of entity, or name of another managed entity (e.g., dummy entities).

rotate.details: Rotates the given entities a certain number of degrees horizontally and vertically from their current rotation.

setblock.details: Sets the block at a specific position, optionally using a replace mode.

fill.details: Fills blocks in a specific region, optionally using a replace mode.

scatter.details: Randomly scatters blocks throughout a region with a certain percentage.

replace.details: Replaces all source blocks with a result block in a specific region.

kill.details: Kills the given entities, causing the death animation, sounds, and particles to appear.

remove.details: Teleports the given entities deep into the void, causing a silent death. Looking to rewrite this in the future to generate entity code for real removal.

clear.details: Clears the inventories of all given entities, optionally searching for a specific item and limiting the number of items to remove.

globaltitle.details: Displays a title on the screen of all players in the game. Can also be used to set the timings of the title. Supports format-strings.

title.details: Displays a title on the screen of the executing player, or to the given one if specified. Can also be used to set the timings of the title. Supports format-strings.

globalactionbar.details: Displays an actionbar on the screen of all players in the game. Can also be used to set the timings of the actionbar. Supports format-strings.

actionbar.details: Displays an actionbar on the screen of the executing player, or to the given one if specified. Supports format-strings.

say.details: Send a plain-text message as the executing entity. Plain selectors can be used, but not variables.

halt.details: Ends the execution of the code entirely by hitting the function command limit.

damage.details: Damages the given entities with a certain cause, optionally coming from a position or blaming an entity by a selector, "name:type" of entity, or name of another managed entity (e.g., dummy entities).

effect.details: Gives the given entities a potion effect. Time and amplifier can be specified to further customize the potion effect. All potion effects can be cleared using 'effect \<selector\> clear'.

playsound.details: Plays a sound effect in the world, optionally with volume, pitch, and filtering specific players.

particle.details: Spawns a particle effect in the world.

dummy.details: Create a dummy entity, remove the selected ones, or manage the classes on the selected ones. Requires feature 'DUMMIES' to be enabled.

tag.details: Add and remove tags from the given entity.

explode.details: Create an explosion at a specific position with optional positioning, power, delay, fire, and block breaking settings. Requires feature 'EXPLODERS' to be enabled.

feature.details: Enables a feature to be used for this project, generating any of the necessary files.

function.details: Defines a function. Must be followed by a code-block. Parameters must have types, optionally having default values. Function calls look like this: `functionName(parameters)`

test.details: Defines a test; requires 'tests' feature. Must be followed by a code-block that contains the test contents.

return.details: Set the value that will be returned from this function when it ends. The caller can use this value however it wishes.

for.details: Runs the following statement or code-block once over every entity that matches a selector at its current position. Functionally equivalent to `execute as <selector> at @s run <code>`

execute.details: Begins a vanilla minecraft 1.19.70+ execute chain. Can be followed by a statement or code-block, but does not explicitly support the 'run' subcommand.
